commit.message:
[Resolves #921] Drop python version 2.7 support (#922)

Python 2.7 is deprecated and it is no longer availble on
Circle CI build VMs. This PR removes python ver 2.7 support
from Sceptre.

commit.message:
[Resolve #489] Add hooks to create_change_set (#908)

Adds before_create_change_set and after_create_change_set hooks.

These are used for "update -c" or "create" for change set.

Hooks for create_change_set are necessary for actions that need to
happen before any update. For example, upload templates for nested
stacks.

Co-authored-by: Niall Grant <ngfgrant@gmail.com>

commit.message:
Fix execution on empty change-sets

Our execute change-set command was attempting to execute all change sets
even if the change-set creation had failed due to no changes.

This commit adds a filter for change-sets that have failed because there
were no changes. Information is logged to the user and sceptre continues
launching all change-sets that were successfully created.

[Resolves #846]

Revert "Update documentation links to new domain"

This reverts commit bd7808a11738e76030698622aef6d8e399763a90.

Update documentation links to new domain

The Sceptre documentation has been moved from `sceptre.cloureach.com` to
`sceptre.github.io`.

commit.message: Fix linting as a result of updated flake

[Resolves #798] complex data for resolvers and hooks (#850)

Allow hooks and resolvers to take complex data objects as arguments.
This is a port of commit ed681aa9 to Sceptre V2
Fix/formatting (#832)

[Resolve #870] Bugfix in _call_sceptre_handler (#871)

Before this, the _call_sceptre_handler method makes multiple calls to
os.getcwd() in determining paths to add and then later paths to remove.
In the event that the sceptre_handler code then makes a call to
os.chdir, the second call ends up removing the wrong path.

This patch ensures that the paths removed are the same ones that are
added.

[Resolves #758] Improve error message for stack_output dependencies (#830)

[Resolve #848] Fix imports (#860)

Importing with a "." causes plugin builds to fail with an ImportError.
Change the "." to a path name.
Fix formatting error in terminology.rst (#854)

[Resolves #571] Add iam_role capability for stack-config (#799)

This allow users to specify `iam_role` in their stack config.
The IAM role is evaluated at the very end after the environment
variables and profile for AWS.

The following order of precedence applies for the stack config:
- Environment variables for AWS are used (access/secret/session)
- The `region` set in the stack config is used
- The `profile` set in the stack config if used
- The `iam_role` is assumed using the current session available

If a user has environment variables, region, profile and iam role
set then it will use the environment variables to create a session
using the defined region in the stack config. It will then assume
the role using that session. The credentials from the profile are
ignored in this case. If environment variables are not present
then the profile will be used if available, otherwise the default
local credentials will be used.

In addition, the stack output external resolver has been modified
to allow for additional arguments separated by double colons (::).

The format now supports profile::region::iam_role and is fully
compatible with current and older versions

The following are all valid examples:
- !stack_output_external Stack::Output profile::eu-west-1::role_arn
  - Creates session from profile, assumes role and uses region
- !stack_output_external Stack::Output ::eu-west-1::role_arn
  - Assumes the role from the default credentials and uses region
- !stack_output_external Stack::Output profile
  - Uses profile, profile can include role and region as well
- !stack_output_external Stack::Output ::::role_arn
  - Assumes the role from the default credentials

Fix Jinja autoescape vulnerability (#853)

Template engines have an HTML autoescape mechanism that protects web
applications against most common cross-site-scripting (XSS)
vulnerabilities.

By default, it automatically replaces HTML special characters in any
template variables. This secure by design configuration should not be
globally disabled.

Escaping HTML from template variables prevents switching into any
execution context, like <script>. Disabling autoescaping forces
developers to manually escape each template variable for the application
to be safe. A more pragmatic approach is to escape by default and to
manually disable escaping when needed.

A successful exploitation of a cross-site-scripting vulnerability by an
attacker allow him to execute malicious JavaScript code in a user's web
browser. The most severe XSS attacks involve:

Forced redirection
Modify presentation of content
User accounts takeover after disclosure of sensitive information like
session cookies or passwords

Template engines have an HTML autoescape mechanism that protects web

Escaping HTML from template variables prevents switching into any
